VOL. XXXI, No. 44

DEAN COMMENTS ON
BANQUET SCUFFLE
Says He Is Loathe to Censure
Youthful Battlers
STUDENT COUNCIL REPORT
Characterizes Affair As "Rough
and Tumble" But Friendly

HOMEWOOD. BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 5, 1927

COTILLON DANCE
TO HONOR YALE
"Bob" Iula will furnish the
musical entertainment at a
(lance to be held at the Belvedere on April 9, it was announced at a recent Cotillon
Club meeting.
Wagner,
George Plater
President of the Club, stated
that the dance, to be given in
honor of the Yale stickmen,
will replace the usual Saturday afternoon Tea Dance.
Music will be "on tap" from
nine until one.
Admission, the same for a
couple or stag, will be one dollar and a half.

Praises Student Council

"At Hopkins," concluded the
Dean, "matters of discipline are
primarily in the hands of the
Student Council, and I have nothing but praise to give our system
of self-government. This body
and other influential groups of
students are giving this whole
matter serious consideration, and
I hope some practicable suggestions will emerge." _
The report of the Council.
about 1,200 words in length, gives
a complete story of the fight from
the arrival of the freshmen until
they left Annapolis. Dean Ames
had asked for a report of facts
Without any criticisms of the conduct of the officials.
Injuries Reported

A detailed account of the manner in which Bernard Brack and
John Turnbull, two sophomores,
Were injured featured the report,
Which also described how the
Other men sent to the hospital received their injuries. An accurate
account is given also of the way
the arrests were made.
The committee summarized
their findings in a concluding parContinued on Page 2, Col. 4

Driver, P. W. Ness, Stevenson, and
C. E. Waters Also Take Part in
Annual Competition

Earl G. Sands was the victor in
the Adams Medal Contest held at
the Assembly last Thursday. This
prize is awarded each year to the
sophomore delivering the best
public declamation. Sands's speech
which was entitled "The Soldier's
Faith," was written by Oliver
Wendell Holmes, and was given
by him at a Harvard class reunion some years ago. The
judges decided in favor of Sands
because of his excellent tone inflection and,forceful gestures, and
because he evidenced much command of his address.

other than that I am convinced
that the facts are as given," stated Dean Joseph S. Ames when
handed the official report by the
Student Council on the recent disturbance between the Sophomore
and freshman classes in Annapolis. "The really important question is what should be done in

"POP" SWINDELL
It is not often that someone, purely "out of the goodness of
his heart," so to speak, devotes a major part of his time to remunerative. work and refuses the remuneration. It is just not done.
Every now and then, however, there crops up one who transcends
ordinary human nature to the extent that he can give something
for nothing.
Every year Walter B. Swindell, Jr., coach of the Barnstormers Club, is offered a salary by the club, and every year it
is declined. He has coached every performance for the past seven
or eight years; and all of them have been excellently produced.
Amateurism in its undesirable forms has been missing from the
Barnstormer presentation.
It is true that Mr. Swindell receives from his efforts the
"craftsman's joy" and the fun of being with "m' boys," but so do
paid coaches in other branches of University activities. He deserves thanks not only from the club itself, but from the entire
student body.
"Pop" is apparently becoming a fixture at Hopkins. We hope
he remains one.

AN AUSPICIOUS START
Critics who were pointing knowingly to the fact that Hopkins
had lost eight lacrosse veterans received somewhat of a jolt last
Saturday. Any of them who braved the weather and wandered
out to Homewood were treated to an attack which, if not quite
as polished as some that have represented the Black and Blue,
certainly showed remarkable form for so early in the season.
The defense had little opportunity to demonstrate its strength,
for the ball was in possession of the Homewood team for almost
the entire duration of the game. We shall have to wait until the
end of the week to see what effect the loss of Levy, Berndt, and
Gerstmyer really has had.
Good lacrosse teams are one tradition at Hopkins that no one
can dispute. 1927 promises to be a traditional year.

DORM STUDENTS PLEASE NOTE
While Miss Louise Alice Williams was giving her recital of
Southern spirituals and stories on Thursday night, the Dormitory
inmates undertook to wage a sham battle with blank pistols in the
vicinity of the Playshop. The Chicagoan outburst may have been
a very interesting diversion for the residents, but it was extremely
disconcerting to Miss Williams's audience.
Even if Hopkins students are prone to rowdyism or lack of
consideration, we feel that a much more opportune time for such
a display could be selected. The cultured, dignified audience
present at the Playshop will hardly retain a favorable impression
of 1-I opkins undergraduates after Thursday night's episode.
This is Baltimore, not Annapolis!

MAILBAG
PURNELL HALL INCENSED
To the Editor of the News-Letter,
Dear Sir:
When I first read Milton Medenbach's letter concerning the
Annapolis affair, which appeared
in last Tuesday's issue of your
paper, I am quite naturally and
However,
rightfully incensed.
after time enough had elapsed in
order to let me view the matter
in the proper perspective, I realized that to a thinking person the
letter in question was ludicrous.
Those who share the views expressed by Medenbach are either
blind and deaf or are guilty of intentional prevarication. I was inside the armory during the entire
fracas and I saw freshmen
neither using their fists nor
wielding weapons of any sort
during any part of the affair. That
the conduct of the policemen is
unjustifiable is admitted by everyone, but to say that the freshmen held their "schooimates"
while the police brutally clubbed
them is erroneous. There was
perhaps one case where a sophomore was held when a policeman
hit him, that is, John Turnbull's,
an occurrence which is deplored
by the entire freshman class. The
Freshmen who were holding him
were doing so in order to prevent
him from overturning tables, not
for the benefit of the police.
As to the freshmen breaking a
tradition in not inviting the sophomores into the banquet, I refer
you to the issue of the News-Letter dated March 25, in which the
President of the freshman class
is quoted as having told the Sophomores gathered outside the
armory "to return in an hour and
view the entertainment which will
follow the meal."
This I feel
covers the question as to our
breaking that tradition.
To say that the freshmen could
have prevented the property damage if they had so desired is both
stupid and ridiculous. Does any
one think that we broke eighteen
windows merely for the pleasure
of paying for them?
Perhaps Milton Medenbach
was writing from hearsay or
newspaper accounts, if that is the
case, I should like to remind him
that there is a great deal in the
saying "seeing is believing."
'The letter I have made past
reference to ends with a question:
"is the freshman class worthy

"That Japan has reverted from
a policy of force in the Far East to
one of peaceful co-operation," was
the thought expressed by Dr.
George H. Blakeslee in his lecture
Friday afternoon on "Japan and
the United States." "Russia," he
said, "may be regarded as the greatest source of danger; whereas Japan, following the policy of the
United States in her demand for the
Open Door, is the greatest instrument of peace."

For full information and other opportunities apply to the
Bureau of Appointments.
Swimming Club desires services of: Four students during summer
months as waiters. Room and board besides regular salary
and tips; and six students for part-time work as waiters at
banquets, etc., three nights a week.
Three Aggressive College Students to solicit orders for specialty
garden furniture in Roland Park, Homeland and Guilford.
List of prospects will be furnished by high grade local Manufacturing Company.
Steamship Company in New York State has opening for clerical
assistants in offices and on boats.
Survey: Covering approximately twenty-five interviews among
Architects, Heating Men, Building Contractors, Real Estate
Men, and Department Stores.

States: a—French and Music; b—Junior High School; c—
Literature and English.
Private Academy in South Atlantic States, two or three
teachers for Mathematics, Science, Latin, Spanish, Athletics.

DEAN COMMENTS ON
BANQUET SCUFFLE
Says He Is Loathe to Censure
Youthful Battlers
STUDENT COUNCIL REPORT
Characterizes Affair As "Rough
and Tumble" But Friendly

HOMEWOOD. BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 5, 1927

COTILLON DANCE
TO HONOR YALE
"Bob" Iula will furnish the
musical entertainment at a
(lance to be held at the Belvedere on April 9, it was announced at a recent Cotillon
Club meeting.
Wagner,
George Plater
President of the Club, stated
that the dance, to be given in
honor of the Yale stickmen,
will replace the usual Saturday afternoon Tea Dance.
Music will be "on tap" from
nine until one.
Admission, the same for a
couple or stag, will be one dollar and a half.

Praises Student Council

"At Hopkins," concluded the
Dean, "matters of discipline are
primarily in the hands of the
Student Council, and I have nothing but praise to give our system
of self-government. This body
and other influential groups of
students are giving this whole
matter serious consideration, and
I hope some practicable suggestions will emerge." _
The report of the Council.
about 1,200 words in length, gives
a complete story of the fight from
the arrival of the freshmen until
they left Annapolis. Dean Ames
had asked for a report of facts
Without any criticisms of the conduct of the officials.
Injuries Reported

A detailed account of the manner in which Bernard Brack and
John Turnbull, two sophomores,
Were injured featured the report,
Which also described how the
Other men sent to the hospital received their injuries. An accurate
account is given also of the way
the arrests were made.
The committee summarized
their findings in a concluding parContinued on Page 2, Col. 4

Driver, P. W. Ness, Stevenson, and
C. E. Waters Also Take Part in
Annual Competition

Earl G. Sands was the victor in
the Adams Medal Contest held at
the Assembly last Thursday. This
prize is awarded each year to the
sophomore delivering the best
public declamation. Sands's speech
which was entitled "The Soldier's
Faith," was written by Oliver
Wendell Holmes, and was given
by him at a Harvard class reunion some years ago. The
judges decided in favor of Sands
because of his excellent tone inflection and,forceful gestures, and
because he evidenced much command of his address.

"POP" SWINDELL
It is not often that someone, purely "out of the goodness of
his heart," so to speak, devotes a major part of his time to remunerative. work and refuses the remuneration. It is just not done.
Every now and then, however, there crops up one who transcends
ordinary human nature to the extent that he can give something
for nothing.
Every year Walter B. Swindell, Jr., coach of the Barnstormers Club, is offered a salary by the club, and every year it
is declined. He has coached every performance for the past seven
or eight years; and all of them have been excellently produced.
Amateurism in its undesirable forms has been missing from the
Barnstormer presentation.
It is true that Mr. Swindell receives from his efforts the
"craftsman's joy" and the fun of being with "m' boys," but so do
paid coaches in other branches of University activities. He deserves thanks not only from the club itself, but from the entire
student body.
"Pop" is apparently becoming a fixture at Hopkins. We hope
he remains one.

AN AUSPICIOUS START
Critics who were pointing knowingly to the fact that Hopkins
had lost eight lacrosse veterans received somewhat of a jolt last
Saturday. Any of them who braved the weather and wandered
out to Homewood were treated to an attack which, if not quite
as polished as some that have represented the Black and Blue,
certainly showed remarkable form for so early in the season.
The defense had little opportunity to demonstrate its strength,
for the ball was in possession of the Homewood team for almost
the entire duration of the game. We shall have to wait until the
end of the week to see what effect the loss of Levy, Berndt, and
Gerstmyer really has had.
Good lacrosse teams are one tradition at Hopkins that no one
can dispute. 1927 promises to be a traditional year.

DORM STUDENTS PLEASE NOTE
While Miss Louise Alice Williams was giving her recital of
Southern spirituals and stories on Thursday night, the Dormitory
inmates undertook to wage a sham battle with blank pistols in the
vicinity of the Playshop. The Chicagoan outburst may have been
a very interesting diversion for the residents, but it was extremely
disconcerting to Miss Williams's audience.
Even if Hopkins students are prone to rowdyism or lack of
consideration, we feel that a much more opportune time for such
a display could be selected. The cultured, dignified audience
present at the Playshop will hardly retain a favorable impression
of 1-I opkins undergraduates after Thursday night's episode.
This is Baltimore, not Annapolis!

MAILBAG
PURNELL HALL INCENSED
To the Editor of the News-Letter,
Dear Sir:
When I first read Milton Medenbach's letter concerning the
Annapolis affair, which appeared
in last Tuesday's issue of your
paper, I am quite naturally and
However,
rightfully incensed.
after time enough had elapsed in
order to let me view the matter
in the proper perspective, I realized that to a thinking person the
letter in question was ludicrous.
Those who share the views expressed by Medenbach are either
blind and deaf or are guilty of intentional prevarication. I was inside the armory during the entire
fracas and I saw freshmen
neither using their fists nor
wielding weapons of any sort
during any part of the affair. That
the conduct of the policemen is
unjustifiable is admitted by everyone, but to say that the freshmen held their "schooimates"
while the police brutally clubbed
them is erroneous. There was
perhaps one case where a sophomore was held when a policeman
hit him, that is, John Turnbull's,
an occurrence which is deplored
by the entire freshman class. The
Freshmen who were holding him
were doing so in order to prevent
him from overturning tables, not
for the benefit of the police.
As to the freshmen breaking a
tradition in not inviting the sophomores into the banquet, I refer
you to the issue of the News-Letter dated March 25, in which the
President of the freshman class
is quoted as having told the Sophomores gathered outside the
armory "to return in an hour and
view the entertainment which will
follow the meal."
This I feel
covers the question as to our
breaking that tradition.
To say that the freshmen could
have prevented the property damage if they had so desired is both
stupid and ridiculous. Does any
one think that we broke eighteen
windows merely for the pleasure
of paying for them?
Perhaps Milton Medenbach
was writing from hearsay or
newspaper accounts, if that is the
case, I should like to remind him
that there is a great deal in the
saying "seeing is believing."
'The letter I have made past
reference to ends with a question:
"is the freshman class worthy

new fire hose will also be bought

The secretary was instructed to
write to the chief of police, asking
for its return.

"That Japan has reverted from
a policy of force in the Far East to
one of peaceful co-operation," was
the thought expressed by Dr.
George H. Blakeslee in his lecture
Friday afternoon on "Japan and
the United States." "Russia," he
said, "may be regarded as the greatest source of danger; whereas Japan, following the policy of the
United States in her demand for the
Open Door, is the greatest instrument of peace."

POSITIONS OPEN TO HOPKINS MEN
For full information and other opportunities apply to the
Bureau of Appointments.
Swimming Club desires services of: Four students during summer
months as waiters. Room and board besides regular salary
and tips; and six students for part-time work as waiters at
banquets, etc., three nights a week.
Three Aggressive College Students to solicit orders for specialty
garden furniture in Roland Park, Homeland and Guilford.
List of prospects will be furnished by high grade local Manufacturing Company.
Steamship Company in New York State has opening for clerical
assistants in offices and on boats.
Survey: Covering approximately twenty-five interviews among
Architects, Heating Men, Building Contractors, Real Estate
Men, and Department Stores.
TEACHERS WANTED: Preparatory School in New England
States: a—French and Music; b—Junior High School; c—
Literature and English.
Private Academy in South Atlantic States, two or three
teachers for Mathematics, Science, Latin, Spanish, Athletics.
